Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Parenting for STEM Success in African American Families

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative proposal focuses on African American parents' racial beliefs and experiences as mechanisms shaping their parenting relevant to youths' science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) success. The purpose of the longitudinal study is to investigate the relationship of parents' race related beliefs to their socialization (particularly their fostering of science and math skills) of their early adolescent children. The project links race as a social identity with parenting and young adolescents' performance in science and mathematics. The investigators will obtain survey data in Grades 6, 7, and 8 from 380 African American students, one of their parents, and their teachers. Hypotheses regarding the relationships between parents' race-related experiences and beliefs (i.e., racial discrimination, knowledge of inequalities, racial identity, and endorsement of race stereotypes) and the academic socialization of their children will be tested. Differences in these processes by child gender and ability will be examined.

The project's intellectual merit is its potential to advance understanding about STEM success for underrepresented youth. The focus will yield new insights in an area where African American youth are likely to face negative stereotypes and discriminatory treatment, and where most prior research has focused on classroom processes rather than parenting. Broader impacts of the work are in the realms of education and training; inclusion of under-represented groups; and dissemination to teachers, families, the public, and to the scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Parenting for STEM Success in African American Parents project acknowledges the important role that parents play in the development of motivation and achievement for youth in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). The study further illustrated the influence of African American parents? race-related experiences and beliefs in shaping their STEM-related socialization strategies. We posit that parents? beliefs about the realities of being Black in the United States inform their views about technical fields such as math and science, areas where African American students are especially likely to underperform. To that end, the study examined whether African American parents? experiences with racial discrimination, awareness of racial academic stereotypes, and their beliefs about the origins of racial achievement gaps influence the ways in which they support their children?s development in STEM courses as they move through middle school. We expect that the results will be used to develop interventions for African American families that will encourage greater participation in advanced STEM coursework and the likelihood that African American students will aspire to STEM-related careers.

The youth in our study were followed annually through the middle school years, Grades 6 to 8. We chose a time when young adolescents are rapidly developing understanding of race and inequality, and when parents begin to talk about race more openly with their children. One parent from each family and youths? science and math teachers also participated. Families were living in one of three low-income, racially diverse school districts.

Our results demonstrate the sometimes subtle ways that race influences the academic outcomes of African American students. They underscore the critical role that parents play as filters of the racialized society in which we live. The general pattern of results suggests that parents? race-related experiences (i.e., racial discrimination) and beliefs (e.g., stereotype endorsement and beliefs about the reasons underlying racial achievement gaps) influence how they talk to their children about race and how they support their children?s STEM learning. This racial socialization and more general STEM socialization on the part of parents was positively associated with achievement outcomes for the students.

We also found a less positive series of relationships. We found that when parents attribute racial achievement gaps to individual causes, such as a lack of effort, motivation, or ability of African American students, they were less likely to encourage their children to be proud to be Black and were more likely to convey negative messages about African Americans. These results were in contrast to the finding that parents who attribute achievement gaps to systemic oppression or inequality were more likely to prepare their children for racial discrimination, more likely to encourage racial pride, and less likely to send negative messages about African Americans. We also found that parents who were more aware of systemic oppression tended to be more involved with their children?s education at home. Given the benefits of racial pride and racial barrier socialization, these results suggest that interventions may encourage African American parents to recognize the ways in which institutions may be biased against African Americans and to focus less on racial stereotypes such as the belief that African Americans lack the ability to excel in school relative to their White counterparts.

The broader impacts of the project lie primarily in the implications of the findings for NSF?s aim of broadening participation of underrepresented minority students in STEM, the training of students from marginalized backgrounds (i.e., unrepresented minority and immigrant students), and the dissemination of results at national conferences and to local partner organizations. One of the most important aspects of the project has been the development of rich relationships with local school personnel. We have shared our expertise with each participating school to address pressing issues that they are facing. These activities include workshops for teachers on reducing racial disparities in disciplinary action, panels for students on how to prepare to go to college, and afterschool activities for students with behavior problems. Results of the project have been shared with parents and teachers.
